channel.title: Anecdotal Evidence on Anecdotal Evidence
channel.description: Recent content in Anecdotal Evidence on Anecdotal Evidence

item.title: #Tidy Tuesday 12-4-2018: Medium Blog Posts
item.description:
So my first attempt at a #TidyTuesday - it’s not quite as easy as DRob makes it look! The data on Medium blog posts was interesting and in good shape, but for my first #TidyTuesday post I had a bit of a brain cramp generating ideas. I’ve been listening to a podcast lately that talks about the importance of a consistent posting schedule for bloggers, so I tried to dig into the relationship between an author’s posting schedule and the number of claps they receive. Unfortunately I didn’t find much; I might dig a little deeper with the full Kaggle dataset in the future and not just the AI related tags.

After spending a little too much time looking into that relationship, I decided to keep things simple for my first post and threw together some straightforward visualizations looking at the distribution of blog posts across days of the week, the most prolific authors, and the posting routines of the individual prolific authors.

Data

library(tidyverse)
library(lubridate)


medium <- read_csv("https://raw.githubusercontent.com/rfordatascience/tidytuesday/master/data/2018-12-04/medium_datasci.csv")

theme_set(theme_light())

On what days of the week are articles typically posted?

library(lubridate)

medium %>%
  unite(date, year, month, day, sep = "-") %>%
  mutate(day = wday(date, label = TRUE)) %>%
  count(day, sort=TRUE) %>%
  ggplot(aes(x=day, y=n, fill = day)) +
  geom_col() +
  labs(title = "Posts per Day of the Week", y = "# of Posts") +
  geom_text(aes(label = n, vjust = -0.3)) +
  theme(legend.position = "none",
        axis.title.x = element_blank())

Makes sense that writers wouldn’t post on weekends - readership is probably less consistent on weekends, and wouldn’t want potentially popular posts to get overlooked.

Who are the most prolific authors?

medium %>%
  count(author, sort = TRUE) %>%
  drop_na() %>%
  top_n(n=10) %>%
  ggplot(aes(x=fct_reorder(author,n), y=n)) +
  geom_point() +
  labs(title = "Most prolific authors", y = "Number of Articles", x = "Author") +
  coord_flip()

What is the posting schedule of the most prolific authors (Top 10 authors)

prolific <- medium %>%
  count(author, sort = TRUE) %>%
  drop_na() %>%
  top_n(n=10)

author_by_day <- medium %>%
  unite(date,year, month, day, sep="-") %>%
  mutate(day = wday(date, label = TRUE)) %>%
  filter(!is.na(author))

author_by_day %>%
  group_by(author,day) %>%
  summarize(posts = n()) %>%
  filter(author %in% prolific$author) %>%
  ggplot(aes(x=factor(day), y=posts, color = author, group = author)) +
  geom_line(size = 1) +
  labs(title = "What is the posting schedule for the top authors?",
       y = "# of Posts") +
  theme(axis.title.x = element_blank())

I guess if you want to be the most prolific writer, it makes sense that you would have a stable publishing schedule, which Yves Mulkers does. Yves also publishes more often on weekends, in contrast to nearly every other author. Synced and Alibaba Cloud appear to take weekends off, while Corsair’s Publishing doesn’t post on Sundays. Yves is just on a different level from everyone else.

Relatively straightforward first #TidyTuesday but thanks for making it all the way to the bottom! Let me know if you have any questions or ways to improve.

item.title: 2017 Reading List
item.description:
1. Strangers in Their Own Land by Arlie Russell Hochschild
  2. The Undoing Project by Michael Lewis
  3. What it Takes by Richard Ben Cramer
  4. Midnight Riot by Ben Aaronovitch
  5. Just Mercy by Bryan Stevenson
  6. Moon Over Soho by Ben Aaronovitch
  7. Data Science for Business by Foster Provost and Tom Fawcett
  8. The Unwinding by George Packer
  9. Whispers Underground by Ben Aaronovitch
  10. Hillbilly Elegy by J.D. Vance
  11. Broken Homes by Ben Aaronovitch
  12. Foxglove Summer by Ben Aaronovitch
  13. The Hanging Tree by Ben Aaronovitch
  14. Evicted by Matthew Desmond
  15. SQL Queries for Mere Mortals by John L. Viescas and Michael J. Hernandez
  16. The Magic of Thinking Big by David J. Schwartz
  17. White Teeth by Zadie Smith
  18. When Breath Becomes Air by Paul Kalanithi
  19. The Attention Merchants by Tim Wu
  20. The Hike by Drew Magary
  21. The Information: A History, a Theory, a Flood by James Gleick
  22. Team of Teams by Gen. Stanley McChrystal
  23. The Innovators by Walter Isaacson
  24. The Master Switch by Tim Wu
  25. Pattern Recognition by William Gibson
  26. Before the Storm by Rick Perlstein
  27. Dark Money by Jane Mayer
  28. The Restaurant at the End of the Universe by Douglas Adams
  29. Principles by Ray Dalio
  30. A Legacy of Spies by John Le Carre
  31. Spook Country by William Gibson
  32. R for Data Science by Hadley Wickham and Garrett Grolemund
  33. The Power Broker: Robert Moses and the Fall of New York by Robert A. Caro
  34. Zero History by William Gibson

item.title: 2018 Reading List
item.description:
1. The Three-Body Problem by Cixin Liu, trans. by Ken Liu
  2. Shoe Dog: A Memoir by the Creator of Nike by Phil Knight
  3. Killers of the Flower Moon: The Osage Murders and the Birth of the FBI by David Grann
  4. Gnomon by Nick Harkaway
  5. The Ocean at the End of the Lane by Neil Gaiman
  6. The Catcher in the Rye by J.D. Salinger
  7. Siddhartha by Herman Hesse
  8. The Ministry of Utmost Happiness by Arundhati Roy
  9. Broken Angels by Richard K. Morgan
  10. The Political Campaign Desk Reference by Michael McNamara
  11. “Surely You’re Joking, Mr. Feynman!” by Richard Feynman
  12. The Fifth Season by N.K. Jemisin
  13. The Obelisk Gate by N.K. Jemisin
  14. The Stone Sky by N.K. Jemisin
  15. White Noise by Don DeLillo
  16. Yes We (Still) Can: Politics In the Age of Obama, Twitter, and Trump by Dan Pfeiffer
  17. The Secret History by Donna Tartt
  18. A Gentleman in Moscow by Amor Towles
  19. Afterparty by Daryl Gregory
  20. Death by Meeting by Patrick Lencioni
  21. Winners Take All: The Elite Charade of Changing the World by Anand Giridharadas
  22. The Color of Law: A Forgotten History of How Our Government Segregated America by Richard Rothstein
  23. Stubborn Attachments by Tyler Cowen
  24. Black Panther: A Nation Under Our Feet Book 1 by Ta-Nehisi Coates

Currently Reading: Open: An Autobiography by Andre Agassi

item.title: Coming Soon
item.description: I plan to use the Projects space for larger, primarily data driven analyses. These larger projects will likely/hopefully tie into multiple blog posts.
